title: Domain 4.5: Given a scenario, modify enterprise capabilities to enhance security.
content:
🔥 Firewall

📜 Rules

  • Define what traffic is allowed or blocked—based on IPs, ports, protocols, etc.

📋 Access Lists

  • Ordered list of rules to permit or deny network traffic—used in routers, firewalls.

🔌 Ports/Protocols

  • Specify which communication methods are allowed—e.g., block Telnet (port 23), allow HTTPS (port 443).

🌐 Screened Subnets

  • Isolated network zones (e.g., DMZ) placed between internal and external networks for added protection.

🛡️ IDS/IPS (Intrusion Detection/Prevention Systems)

📈 Trends

  • Identify abnormal behavior based on traffic patterns—used for early detection of threats.

✍️ Signatures

  • Pattern-matching rules to detect known attacks—works like antivirus for network traffic.

🌐 Web Filter

👤 Agent-Based

  • Installed on endpoints to control and monitor web traffic directly.

🧭 Centralized Proxy

  • Routes user web traffic through a secure server—allows content control and logging.

🔗 URL Scanning

  • Analyzes websites or links in real-time to block malicious or inappropriate destinations.

🗂️ Content Categorization

  • Groups websites by type (e.g., gambling, social media) for filtering policies.

🚫 Block Rules

  • Explicitly deny access to certain URLs or categories.

🧪 Reputation

  • Uses known risk ratings of websites to allow/block access dynamically.

🖥️ Operating System Security

🏛️ Group Policy

  • Centralized way to enforce security settings (e.g., password policies, user restrictions) across Windows systems.

🐧 SELinux (Security-Enhanced Linux)

  • Linux kernel security module that enforces strict access controls using mandatory access control (MAC) rules.

🔐 Implementation of Secure Protocols

🔁 Protocol Selection

  • Choose secure alternatives (e.g., HTTPS over HTTP, SFTP over FTP) to ensure encrypted communications.

🔌 Port Selection

  • Limit use to necessary and secure ports—helps reduce the attack surface and prevent scanning-based attacks.

🛣️ Transport Method

  • Decide how data moves (e.g., TLS, VPN, IPsec)—ensure encryption and integrity for sensitive traffic.

🌐 DNS Filtering

  • Blocks access to malicious or unwanted domains by checking DNS requests—useful against phishing and malware domains.

📧 Email Security

📬 DMARC (Domain-based Message Authentication Reporting & Conformance)

  • Ensures that email from your domain is properly authenticated using SPF/DKIM—and provides reports on failures.

🔐 DKIM (DomainKeys Identified Mail)

  • Digitally signs emails so recipients can verify they weren’t tampered with in transit.

🛑 SPF (Sender Policy Framework)

  • Specifies which mail servers are authorized to send on behalf of your domain—prevents spoofing.

🚪 Gateway

  • Email security appliance or service that filters and inspects messages before they reach internal inboxes.

🗂️ File Integrity Monitoring (FIM)

  • Monitors files (especially system or config files) for unauthorized changes—alerts on tampering or malware activity.

🛡️ DLP (Data Loss Prevention)

  • Prevents unauthorized transfer of sensitive data—scans emails, USB usage, cloud sync, and more to stop leaks.

🌐 Network Access Control (NAC)

  • Controls which devices can connect to the network—uses posture checks (e.g., up-to-date antivirus) before granting access.

💻 EDR / XDR

EDR (Endpoint Detection & Response)

  • Monitors and responds to threats on individual endpoints—offers real-time detection, isolation, and investigation tools.

XDR (Extended Detection & Response)

  • Integrates data across multiple sources (endpoints, networks, cloud) for a broader, more coordinated response.

🧠 User Behavior Analytics (UBA or UEBA)

  • Analyzes user behavior patterns to detect anomalies—flags suspicious activity like unusual logins or data access.
